sub_topic: Calculation of the electrical conductivity of a metal
message_1: What is the electrical conductivity of a copper wire of length 1 meter and cross-sectional area 1 mm² at a temperature of 20°C, given that the resistivity of copper at this temperature is 1.68 x 10⁻⁸ Ωm? Assume that the wire is made up of a single crystal of copper.
message_2:
To find the electrical conductivity of the copper wire, we first need to find its resistance using the formula:

Resistance (R) = Resistivity (ρ) × Length (L) / Cross-sectional Area (A)

Given:
Resistivity (ρ) = 1.68 x 10⁻⁸ Ωm
Length (L) = 1 meter
Cross-sectional Area (A) = 1 mm² = 1 x 10⁻⁶ m² (converting to square meters)

Now, we can calculate the resistance:

R = (1.68 x 10⁻⁸ Ωm) × (1 m) / (1 x 10⁻⁶ m²)
R = 1.68 x 10⁻² Ω

Now that we have the resistance, we can find the electrical conductivity (σ) using the formula:

Conductivity (σ) = 1 / Resistivity (ρ)

σ = 1 / (1.68 x 10⁻⁸ Ωm)
σ = 5.95 x 10⁷ S/m (Siemens per meter)

So, the electrical conductivity of the copper wire is 5.95 x 10⁷ S/m.
